question: Question_05_(c)
statement:
Alice wants Bob to send her a secret integer \emph{P} between 0 and 1250
using RSA encryption with key $\displaystyle (e, n) = (1189, 1271)$ (so
the exponent is 1189 and the modulus is 1271, it is way too small to be
really secure, but basic RSA encryption and decryption methods still
work of course).

\textbf{(c)} Explain what Alice has to do next to obtain \emph{P} back.
sols:
Recall up to this point that Bob computed
$\displaystyle C \equiv P^{e} \mod{n}$ and you've computed a \emph{d}
such that $\displaystyle ed \equiv 1 \mod{\phi(n)}$ so in fact, we have
$\displaystyle ed = 1 + \phi(n)s$ for some integer \emph{s}. Using
Euler's Theorem, we can compute \emph{P} back if we compute

$\displaystyle C^{d} \equiv (P^{e})^{d} \equiv P^{ed} \equiv P^{1 + \phi(n)s} \equiv P(P^{\phi(n)})^{s} \equiv P \mod{n}$.

This is computable since Alice has both \emph{C} and \emph{d} available
to her. This completes the proof.
